note: Vestwell 是一家总部位于纽约的用于工作场所储蓄和投资计划的 API 技术平台，在 C 系列融资中筹集了 7000 万美元。 Wells Fargo Strategic Capital 和 Fin Venture Capital 共同领投，高盛、摩根士丹利、宏利、Point72、Nationwide Ventures、Allianz Life Ventures、Northwestern Mutual、FinTech Collective、Greenspring Associates、Primary Venture Partners、Teamworthy Ventures 跟投、F-Prime Capital、Industry Ventures 和 Commerce Ventures。该公司打算利用这笔资金进一步扩大团队、平台功能，并为其数千名合作伙伴和客户提供服务。在创始人兼首席执行官 Aaron Schumm 的领导下，Vestwell 为工作场所储蓄和投资计划（例如 401(k) 和 403(b) 退休计划）提供了一个基于云的数字记录保存平台。该公司基于 API 的技术旨在支持金融服务和金融科技公司的多元化生态系统，从注册投资顾问和薪资提供商到银行、经纪交易商、信用合作社、保险公司、资产管理公司等。通过这些合作伙伴关系，Vestwell 使高质量的工作场所储蓄计划变得可及且负担得起，特别是在服务不足的小型企业市场。 Vestwell 作为一家小型计划提供商，为包括 Morgan Stanley 和 Voya 在内的数千家家喻户晓的计划提供支持，同时与 Toast、QuickBooks Payroll、Gusto、Rippling 和 Paylocity 等薪资提供商进行整合和合作。
note_en:
Vestwell, a NYC-based API technology platform for workplace savings and investing programs, raised $70m in Series C financing.
  Wells Fargo Strategic Capital and Fin Venture Capital co-led the round, along with participation from Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Manulife, Point72, Nationwide Ventures, Allianz Life Ventures, Northwestern Mutual, FinTech Collective, Greenspring Associates, Primary Venture Partners, Teamworthy Ventures, F-Prime Capital, Industry Ventures, and Commerce Ventures.
 The company intends to use the funds to further expand the team, platform functionality, and servicing for its thousands of partners and clients.
 Led by Aaron Schumm, Founder and CEO, Vestwell provides a cloud-based digital recordkeeping platform for workplace savings and investing programs, such as 401(k) and 403(b) retirement plans. The company’s API-based technology is designed to support a diverse ecosystem of financial services and fintech companies from registered investment advisors and payroll providers, to banks, broker-dealers, credit unions, insurers, asset managers, and more. Through these partnerships, Vestwell makes quality workplace savings programs accessible and affordable, particularly in the underserved small business market.
 Vestwell works as a small plan provider to help power thousands of plans for household names including Morgan Stanley and Voya, while integrating and partnering with payroll providers such as Toast, QuickBooks Payroll, Gusto, Rippling, and Paylocity.
title: Vestwell 为其基于 API 的技术筹集了 7000 万美元 C 系列，该技术帮助雇主，尤其是小企业，管理员工退休计划
title_en: Vestwell raises $70M Series C for its API-based technology that helps employers, particularly small businesses, manage staff retirement plans

note:
Loop Returns 是由 Jonathan Poma 共同创立的，当时他在一家代理机构工作，并为一个大的 Shopify 品牌提供咨询，以帮助他们进行退货和换货。他与老朋友 Corbett Morgan 合作创办了 Loop Returns。该软件与 Shopify 平台配合使用，以降低零售中常见问题（退货）的成本和难度。事实上，据 Shopify 称，退货占电子商务销售额的 20% 到 30%。对于大品牌和小品牌来说，这种趋势不仅要花钱，而且可能会失去客户和未来的收入。 Loop 通过引导用户回答一系列旨在保持其业务的问题来接近回报。它从有关商品尺寸的问题开始，然后转向交换的概念，然后通过退货向客户提供品牌信用。如果客户只想要退货，Loop 会处理该过程中的一些棘手问题，例如运输标签和品牌退款。在大流行之前，该公司围绕国际扩张、平台扩张和产品扩张制定了宏伟计划。最终，那个黑天鹅时刻使公司专注于其核心产品和照顾客户，并取得了回报，尤其是在电子商务加速发展之后。该公司已将其团队从 2019 年的 20 名员工增加到 100 名，其中 41% 的团队成员为女性，16% 为 BIOC。在牵引力方面，该公司的客户已从 200 名增加到 700 名，同时处理的退货从 2600 万美元增加到略高于 1 亿美元。
Poma 说：“这是为了让优秀的人聚集在一起，让他们朝着一个共同的目标前进，尤其是在这个偏远的第一世界。”
note_en:
Loop Returns was co-founded by Jonathan Poma after he was working at an agency and consulting with a big Shopify brand to help them with returns and exchanges. He partnered with longtime friend Corbett Morgan to start Loop Returns.
  The software works with the Shopify platform to reduce the cost and difficulty with a commonplace issue in retail, which is returns. In fact,  according to Shopify, returns account for 20 to 30% of e-commerce sales. For big and small brands alike, this is a trend that not only costs money, but potentially loses a customer and future revenue.
 Loop approaches the return by navigating the user through a series of questions aimed at keeping their business. It starts with questions around sizing of the item, and then moves to the notion of an exchange, and then offers the customer credit with the brand over a return.
  If a return is all the customer wants, Loop handles some of the stickier pieces of that process, such as shipping labels and refunds for the brand.
 The company had big plans around international expansion, platform expansion and product expansion ahead of the pandemic. Ultimately, that Black Swan moment led the company to focus on its core offering and taking care of its customers, and it paid off, especially on the heels of the acceleration of e-commerce.
 The company has grown its team from 20 employees in 2019 to 100, with 41% of the team identifying as female and 16% identifying as BIPOC.
 In terms of traction, the company has gone from 200 to 700 customers, and from $26 million in returns processed to just over $100 million in the same time frame.
   “It’s about bringing great people and keeping them aligned toward a common goal, especially in this remote first world,” said Poma.
title: Loop Returns 的软件使 Shopify 上的商店能够处理在线退货，以 3.4 亿美元的投后估值筹集了 6500 万美元的 B 轮融资，由 CRV 领投
title_en: Loop Returns, whose software enables stores on Shopify to handle online returns, raises $65M Series B led by CRV at a post-money valuation of $340M

路透莫斯科 7 月 22 日 - 俄罗斯法院周四对美国社交媒体公司 Facebook (FB.O) 和 Twitter (TWTR.N) 处以罚款，原因是他们未能删除非法内容，这是俄罗斯与大型科技公司之间对峙的最新一起。最近几个月，俄罗斯当局采取措施，通过对内容违规行为处以小额罚款，更严格地监管科技巨头，同时还寻求迫使外国公司在俄罗斯开设办事处，并将俄罗斯人的个人数据存储在其领土上。阅读更多 莫斯科的塔甘斯基地方法院表示，它已就两项不同的行政违法行为对 Facebook 处以总计 600 万卢布（81,320 美元）的罚款，这些违法行为与规定网站所有者删除被禁信息或面临处罚有关。法院对 Twitter 的两项违法行为共处以 550 万卢布的罚款。法院称，消息应用 Telegram 还被勒令为三项罪行支付总计 1100 万卢布的赔偿金。其他国家已呼吁社交媒体公司对内容进行更多监管。英国首相鲍里斯约翰逊上周会见了平台代表，并警告说，除非他们删除仇恨和种族主义内容，否则他们将面临相当于其全球收入 10% 的罚款。国家通讯监管机构 Roskomnadzor 表示，自 3 月以来，推特 (TWTR.N) 在俄罗斯因包含儿童色情内容、药物滥用信息或呼吁未成年人自杀的帖子而受到惩罚性放缓。 Twitter 否认允许其平台被用于宣传非法行为，并表示其对儿童性剥削采取零容忍政策，并禁止宣传自杀或自残。
Maxim Rodionov 和 Andrey Ostroukh 的补充报道； Andrew Osborn 和 Pravin Char 编辑
note_en:
MOSCOW, July 22 (Reuters) - A Russian court fined U.S. social media firms Facebook  (FB.O) and Twitter  (TWTR.N) on Thursday for failing to delete illegal content, the latest salvo in a standoff between Russia and Big Tech.
 Russian authorities have taken steps in recent months to regulate technology giants more closely by imposing small fines for content violations, while also seeking to force foreign companies to open offices in Russia and store Russians' personal data on its territory.   read more
 Moscow's Tagansky District Court said it had fined Facebook a total of 6 million roubles ($81,320) for two different administrative offences related to stipulations that website owners delete banned information or face penalties.
 The court fined Twitter a combined 5.5 million roubles for two offences. Messaging app Telegram was also ordered to pay a total of 11 million roubles for three offences, the court said.
  Other countries have called upon social media firms to do more to police content. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson met representatives of platforms last week and warned that they would face fines amounting to 10% of their global revenues unless they removed hateful and racist content.   read more
 Twitter  (TWTR.N) has been subjected to a punitive slowdown in Russia since March for posts containing child pornography, drug abuse information or calls for minors to commit suicide, state communications regulator Roskomnadzor has said.
 Twitter denies allowing its platform to be used to promote illegal behaviour, and says it has a zero-tolerance policy for child sexual exploitation and prohibits the promotion of suicide or self-harm.
  Additional reporting by Maxim Rodionov and Andrey Ostroukh; editing by Andrew Osborn and Pravin Char
title: 路透社

路透社 7 月 22 日 - Facebook（FB.O）长期以来一直在寻求您的关注。最近几周，它已经开始在一个现在可用于美国 Facebook 群组的新工具中请求您的祈祷。祈祷功能是 Facebook 最近与宗教界协调一致的外展活动的一部分，这是 Facebook 首次向媒体详细谈论这一点。 Facebook 将信徒视为推动全球最大社交媒体平台参与度的重要社区。早在 2017 年，首席执行官马克·扎克伯格 (Mark Zuckerberg) 就在一份关于连接世界的冗长宣言中以教堂为例，该公司创建了一个专注于“信仰伙伴关系”的团队。 Facebook 的信仰伙伴关系负责人诺娜·琼斯在接受路透社采访时告诉路透社，COVID 为这些努力赋予了新的紧迫性。琼斯也是佛罗里达州的一名牧师，他说，在该公司看到在大流行期间互相祈求祈祷的人数有所增加后，推出了新的祈祷产品。上个月，该公司与宗教领袖举行了首次虚拟信仰峰会。在 Facebook Live 的现场直播活动中，当宗教领袖为他们的会众服务时，该公司播放了屏幕上漂浮着心形表情符号的视频，首席运营官雪莉·桑德伯格 (Sheryl Sandberg) 讨论了未来领袖与信徒使用虚拟现实工具和增强现实互动的未来。 5 月底，Facebook 推出了它的祈祷工具，它已经在一些信仰社区中进行了测试，所有美国 Facebook 群组都可以打开该工具。在路透社看到的一个私人团体中，一名妇女使用该工具为一位患有冠状病毒的阿姨祈祷。人们通过点击一个按钮说“我祈祷了”来回答，他们的名字被数在下面。用户可以选择收到通知，提醒他们明天再次祈祷。其他人要求为女儿的心碎、儿子的驾驶考试和保险公司的问题祈祷。琼斯证实，祈祷帖用于个性化 Facebook 上的广告，就像其他内容一样。一位发言人表示，这些数据可能会影响 Facebook 的机器学习系统如何决定向用户展示哪些广告。这位知情人士说，广告商将无法根据祈祷的内容或功能的使用直接定位广告。该发言人还表示，广告购买者已经根据对“信仰”或“天主教会”等主题表现出的兴趣来划分 Facebook 受众的类别，不会将祈祷工具的使用纳入考虑范围。 “使用 Facebook 产品进行联系的最大社区之一是有信仰的人，”即将离任的 Facebook 应用程序负责人 Fidji Simo 在峰会的炉边聊天中说，随后与宗教领袖座谈会以及精神呼吸、呼吸和冥想练习。 .
“当我查看大流行期间发生的事情的数据时，我们看到精神类别的巨大增长。”在大流行初期，Facebook 向宗教团体发送了小型三脚架和手机座等设备的“入门套件”，用于在礼拜场所关闭时进行直播和拍摄内容。它推出了一个信仰资源网站，提供电子学习课程和最佳实践测验，并宣称“你的礼拜堂想要接触的人已经在 Facebook 平台上。”今年，它成立了一个跨信仰咨询委员会，定期与信仰领袖和教育工作者举行会议。除了咨询宗教领袖 - 他们告诉路透社他们对该网站的愿望清单包括教堂规划工具和显示更多不同形式崇拜的表情符号 - Facebook 一直在挑选已经运行大型在线信仰平台的组织的大脑，例如福音派大型教堂 Life.Church，牧师凯尔·库特说。虽然许多与路透社交谈的宗教领袖在他们的社区被迫呆在家里的一年里对 Facebook 的关注表示欢迎，但一些群组用户提到了对祈祷帖隐私的担忧，质疑他们的精神活动如何在网上被利用，或者说他们发现它临床。 Simcha Fisher 是一个天主教妇女 Facebook 群组的成员，她说她只看到朋友们使用的祈祷帖，他们认为它感觉“恶心”。她的朋友将 Facebook 比作一个专横的父母参与平台上自然发生的互动：“任何时候 Facebook 推出新的东西，你知道这是因为他们希望从中赚钱......最终以某种方式卖给你一些东西，”费舍尔说。一些宗教领袖和团体成员表示，他们希望看到 Facebook 在发起祈祷以处理针对网站上针对其社区的虐待行为时所表现出的同样程度的承诺。 Khizer Subhani 在湾区为穆斯林经营 Facebook 群组，该群组可以提前使用祈祷功能，他说他欢迎该公司的关注，但权衡了他对 Facebook 处理平台上宗教团体仇恨言论的挫败感。对于面临全球监管机构和立法者攻击的 Facebook 而言，包括未能遏制暴力言论和疫苗错误信息等有害内容的记录，在全球大流行期间连接信徒是它表示希望加倍努力的那种应用程序.桑德伯格在峰会上说，信仰社区代表了“Facebook 最好的一面，我们希望现在和将来都保持这种状态”。
note_en:
July 22 (Reuters) - Facebook  (FB.O) has long sought your attention. In recent weeks, it has started asking for your prayers as well in a new tool now available for U.S. Facebook Groups.
 The prayer feature is part of Facebook's recent and concerted outreach to the religious community, which it is speaking about in detail to media for the first time. Facebook sees worshippers as a vital community to drive engagement on the world's largest social media platform. As early as 2017, CEO Mark Zuckerberg cited churches as one example in a lengthy manifesto on connecting the world and the company created a team focused on "faith partnerships."
 COVID gave new urgency to the efforts, Facebook's head of faith partnerships Nona Jones told Reuters in an interview. The new prayers product was spun up after the company saw an increase in people asking each other for prayers during the pandemic, said Jones, who is also a pastor in Florida.
 The outreach culminated in the company holding its first virtual faith summit with religious leaders last month. During the live event broadcast on Facebook Live where the company played videos with heart emojis floating across the screen as religious leaders ministered to their congregations, Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg discussed a future where leaders engaged worshippers with virtual reality tools and augmented reality.
 At the end of May, Facebook made its prayer tool, which it had been testing with some faith communities, accessible for all U.S. Facebook Groups to turn on. In one private Group seen by Reuters, a woman used the tool to request prayers for an aunt sick with coronavirus. People replied by clicking a button to say "I prayed," and their names were counted underneath. Users could choose to be notified with a reminder to pray again tomorrow. Others requested prayers for a daughter's broken heart, a son's driving test and problems with an insurance company.
 Jones confirmed prayer posts are used to personalize ads on Facebook, like other content. A spokesperson said the data could feed into how Facebook's machine learning systems decide which ads to show users. Advertisers will not be able to directly target ads based on the content of the prayer or use of the feature, the person said. The spokesperson also said prayer tool use would not be factored into the categories that ad buyers already use to slice up Facebook audiences based on a demonstrated interest in topics, like "faith," or "Catholic Church."
 "One of the biggest communities using Facebook products to connect are people of faith," said outgoing Facebook app head Fidji Simo, in a fireside chat at the summit, following panels with religious leaders and a session for spiritual breathwork, a breathing and meditation exercise.
 "When I looked at the data of what was taking off during the pandemic, we were seeing massive growth in the spiritual category."
 Early in the pandemic, Facebook sent "starter kits" of equipment like small tripods and phone holders to faith groups for live-streaming and shooting content as places of worship closed down. It launched a faith resources website with e-learning courses and quizzes on best practices, touting that "the people your house of worship wants to reach are on Facebook platforms already."
 This year, it has started up an Interfaith Advisory Council to hold regular meetings with faith leaders and educators. As well as consulting religious leaders - who told Reuters their wish lists for the site included church planning tools and emojis showing more diverse forms of worship - Facebook has been picking the brains of organizations already running large online faith platforms like evangelical megachurch Life.Church, pastor Kyle Kutter said.
  While many religious leaders who spoke to Reuters welcomed Facebook's attention in a year when their communities were forced to stay at home, some Group users cited concerns over the privacy of prayer posts, questioning how their spiritual activities could be exploited online, or said they found it clinical.
 Simcha Fisher, a member of a Catholic women's Facebook Group, said she had only seen the prayer post used by friends who noted it felt "icky." Her friend had compared Facebook to an overbearing parent getting involved in interactions occurring naturally on the platform: "Anytime Facebook rolls out something new, you know it's because they're hoping to make money off it...to eventually sell you something, somehow," Fisher said.
 Some religious leaders and Group members said they wanted to see the same level of commitment Facebook had shown in launching prayers to dealing with abuse targeted at their communities on the site. Khizer Subhani, who runs a Facebook Group for Muslims in the Bay Area which was given early access to the prayers feature, said he welcomed the company's focus but weighed it against his frustrations over Facebook's handling of hate speech around religious groups on the platform.
 For Facebook, which faces attacks from global regulators and lawmakers, including over its track record of failing to curb harmful content like violent rhetoric and vaccine misinformation, connecting the faithful during a global pandemic is the kind of application it says it wants to double down on. Faith communities represent "the best of Facebook and we hope to keep it that way, now and in the future," Sandberg said at the summit.
title: 看看 Facebook 的祈祷功能及其与信仰团体的联系，Facebook 称这在大流行期间被赋予了新的紧迫性
title_en: A look at Facebook's prayers feature and its outreach with faith groups, which Facebook says was given new urgency during the pandemic

通知出现在网站、门票和剧院外的标牌上：“这是一场无电话活动。”人们在大厅里围着聊天、发短信和 Snapchat 聊天，但当他们走向座位时，服务员指示他们将手机静音并将它们锁在灰绿色的 Yondr 小袋中。 '什么？！为什么？'我听到有人问，她把手机递过去，不忍自己锁了起来。其他人看起来安静地受了打击。但当 Chris Rock 开玩笑时，人们会同时嘲笑同样的台词。没有人高举手机记录这一刻。洛克可以看到我们的脸并适应我们，我们也适应他。集体的笑声（以及偶尔的呻吟声）建立了能量，产生了一个反馈循环，当我们大家一起实时体验时，这种反馈循环提高了表演水平。然后灯亮了，人们直奔邮袋解锁站。他们拿出手机，沐浴在屏幕的光芒中，如释重负，通常没有离开或走向出口。解锁手机就像破解咒语。在那之前，感觉每个在场的人都还活着、清醒，并且是一个单一有机体的一部分——这是我多年来在现场表演中从未有过的感觉。有时我会考虑尝试在其他地方重现这种效果，尽管如果我这样做了，我可能不会被邀请参加很多聚会。但我想知道 - 有多少人会寻找没有电话的地方？当 Instagram 帖子或 TikTok 视频似乎与实际体验一样重要时，人们会故意居住在没有人使用手机的空间吗？电话使用是我们带入共享空间的个人习惯。即使在假期，人们每天也会查看手机大约 80 次。多亏了电话，我们可以在公共场合进行我们过去在私下或专门为他们指定的地方进行的活动：我们认真交谈、打架、买衣服、工作、查看电子邮件、支付账单、看色情片、听音乐，玩游戏，制作视频。在公共场所做所有这些事情意味着我们集体使用手机会塑造环境。以这种方式使用我们的手机可能会造成其他人不由自主地遭受的不愉快情况。任何曾经被困在封闭空间（例如公共汽车）中，有人在电话中大声说话的人都知道这种情况。 Kio Stark 是纽约大学互动电信项目的讲师，他的工作重点是人们与技术的关系，他指出使用电话会导致人们将公共空间视为私人空间。她认为，模糊公共空间和私人空间之间的界限会导致疏离，而不是联系。如果电话交谈渗入了其他人的空间，他们可能会更加努力地将它——以及其他人——拒之门外。研究表明，手机将我们隔离在自己的泡泡中，导致我们对他人说话和微笑的次数减少。放弃建立联系的机会会破坏个人幸福感以及社会氛围。不列颠哥伦比亚大学的心理学家在 2013 年发现，与那些为了更“高效”而放弃此类手势的人相比，微笑、眼神交流和随意与咖啡店咖啡师聊天的人会体验到情绪的提升。我们的习惯很容易忘记愉快互动的好处：芝加哥大学的研究人员在 2014 年发现，人们低估了与他人互动的积极影响，尤其是陌生人。
我们用这些积极的互动换取什么？ Facebook 让人们更加孤独和悲伤，并鼓励我们重视互动的数量而不是质量。研究表明，许多年轻人感到孤立无援，18-22 岁（或 Z 世代）是“最孤独的人”。虽然这不能完全归因于手机使用，但智能手机无济于事。在 2019 年秋季学期，我的一位波士顿大学学生描述了一个周五晚上在一个俱乐部的舞池里，周围是闪烁的灯光和旋转的 20 岁年轻人。即使在跳舞时，他也经常查看手机，“不禁觉得[他的]生活不如其他人那么有趣”。当如此多的人体验到同样的疏远感并且似乎无法突破多巴胺反馈循环时，这些循环使我们陷入无休止的发帖、检查、刷新、喜欢和评论模式，我们的共享空间就会受到影响。如果您曾经在地铁上抬头看到每个人都沉浸在手机中，或者在餐厅环顾四周看到人们（包括约会的情侣）都在手机上，那么您可能已经注意到这一点。这就是为什么文化和技术历史学家、《为什么事物咬回：技术和意外后果的报复》（1997）的作者爱德华·特纳提倡“有意创造和保护无技术空间”的原因之一。 Hannah Gadsby、Alicia Keys、Dave Chappelle、Ariana Grande 和 Jack White 等表演者使用 Yondr 在他们的表演中创造这些空间。一些医院、法院和学校现在也使用它们，人们可以租用它们举办婚礼、会议和聚会。除了小袋，许多火车都有安静的车厢。一些餐馆为不使用电话的食客提供折扣；其他人则完全禁止手机。这些例子标志着无电话空间的更大趋势。禁止使用手机是有危险的。许多人，包括残障人士，依靠手机安全地导航和与环境互动。根据 Tenner 的说法，非自愿的技术超时可能会导致断线焦虑。理想的解决方案不是完全禁止手机，而是创造一个期望与他人和周围环境互动的环境。越来越多的研究表明，大众已经为这种解决方案做好了准备。根据皮尤研究中心的数据，美国 54% 的青少年和 36% 的父母认为他们在自己的手机上花费了太多时间，而 65% 的父母担心孩子的手机使用，大约一半的青少年注意到手机会分散他们父母的注意力。尽管一直盯着手机，但我的大学生对他们日益减少的面对面互动表示失望。一位前学生科尔戈德堡在一封电子邮件中提到，他最喜欢的时间是周五晚上在查巴德，因为安息日而没有电话使用。人们聚在一起吃晚饭，有时整晚都待在那里，享受在其他情况下不可能进行的不间断对话。 “我认为我们都需要每周一次的 Chabad，”戈德伯格写道。仅仅在社交空间中使用手机就会造成人际距离。埃塞克斯大学的研究人员在 2012 年进行的两项实验发现，坐在桌子旁并放着电话（未使用）的人会感到“与伴侣的亲密程度降低，并且报告的人际关系质量低于伴侣”谁在没有手机的情况下分享了对话”。如果受试者讨论特别私人的事情，这些距离效应就会被放大。无电话空间将焦点转移回社交互动，这可以帮助人们通过屏幕建立我们尝试建立的亲密关系，但通常不成功。在佛蒙特州伯灵顿举办的一个名为 Sync 的活动将志同道合的人团结在一起，他们希望亲自联系。该活动的标语是“与陌生人出去玩”。把你的手机留在家里。 2019 年夏天，Yondr 在美国举办了第一个无电话音乐和露营节。在纽约州举行的为期三天的活动有 300 多名与会者。此类活动将重视第一手体验重要性的人们聚集在一起，以便他们可以共同创造和塑造自己的体验。不能或不会放弃他们的设备的人可以选择避免此类聚会，但对于那些寻求有意义的个人互动的人来说，他们可能会成为圣地。
随着人们在日益以技术为中心的世界中寻求满足感，我们中的更多人似乎准备抵制无处不在的手机，转而优先考虑第一手体验。 Yondr 的音乐节在 Woodstock 成立 50 周年之际举行——这是重新评估此类聚会目的的绝佳时机。如果人们在 Jimi Hendrix、Janis Joplin 和 The Who 表演时沉浸在手机中，如果人群中无数人高举手机，记录表演而不是真正体验表演，会失去什么？把手机放在一边，让我们能够享受那些在社交媒体的喧嚣中迷失的时刻——我们只能体验一次的时刻。
note_en:
The notice appeared on the website, the ticket and on signs outside the theatre: ‘This is a phone-free event.’ People milled around the lobby talking, texting, and Snapchatting, but as they headed to their seats, attendants instructed them to silence their phones and lock them inside grey-and-green Yondr pouches. ‘What?!  Why?’ I heard someone ask as she handed over her phone, unable to bear locking it up herself. Others looked quietly stricken.
 But as Chris Rock cracked jokes, people laughed at the same lines at the same time. No one held a phone aloft to record the moment. Rock could see our faces and adjust to us, and we to him. The collective laughter (and the occasional groan) built energy, generating a feedback loop that heightened the show as we all experienced it together, in real time.
 And then the lights came on and people beelined for the pouch-unlocking stations. They unearthed their phones and bathed, relieved, in the glow of their screens, often without stepping aside or moving toward the exit. Unlocking the phones was like breaking a spell. Until then, it had felt like everyone in attendance was alive, awake, and part of a single organism – a feeling I hadn’t had at a live performance in years.
 Sometimes I think about trying to reproduce this effect elsewhere, though I probably wouldn’t be invited to many parties if I did. But then I wonder – how many people would seek out phone-free places? When an Instagram post or TikTok video seems to matter as much as an actual experience, would people intentionally inhabit spaces where no one’s using a phone?
 Phone use is an individual habit that we bring with us into shared spaces. Even on vacation, people check their phones roughly 80 times a day. Thanks to phones, we conduct activities in public that we used to do in private or in places specifically designated for them: we have serious conversations, get in fights, buy clothes, do work, check emails, pay bills, watch porn, listen to music, play games, make videos. Doing all of these things in public spaces means our collective phone use  shapes the environment.
 Using our phones in this way can create unpleasant situations to which others are involuntarily subjected. Anyone who’s ever been trapped in an enclosed space, such as a bus, with someone talking loudly on a phone knows this scenario. Kio Stark, an instructor on the Interactive Telecommunications Program at New York University, whose work focuses on how people relate to technology, notes that phone use results in people treating public space as private space. She believes that blurring the lines between public and private spaces results in alienation, rather than connection. If a phone conversation infiltrates other people’s space, they’ll likely try even harder to shut it – and other people – out.
 Research  shows that phones insulate us into our own bubbles, causing us to talk and smile less at other people. Passing up opportunities for connection undermines individual happiness, as well as the social atmosphere. Psychologists at the University of British Columbia in 2013  found that people who smile, make eye contact, and casually chat with the coffee shop barista experience a mood boost when compared with those who forego such gestures in order to be more ‘efficient’. Our habits can make the benefits of pleasant interactions easy to forget: researchers at the University of Chicago in 2014  found that people underestimate the positive impacts of interacting with others, particularly strangers.
 What are we trading those positive interactions for? Facebook  makes people lonelier and sadder, and encourages us to value quantity over quality of interaction. Research indicates that many young people feel isolated and friendless, and that those aged 18-22 (or Generation Z) are the ‘ loneliest’. While that can’t entirely be attributed to phone use, smartphones don’t help. In the fall semester of 2019, one of my Boston University students described a Friday night on the dance floor of a club surrounded by flashing lights and gyrating 20-year-olds. Even while dancing, he constantly checked his phone and ‘couldn’t help but feel like [his] life is less fun than everybody else’s’.
 When so many people experience the same alienating feeling and can’t seem to break through the dopamine feedback loops that ensnare us in endless patterns of posting, checking, refreshing, liking and commenting, our shared spaces suffer. You’ve probably noticed this if you’ve ever looked up on the subway and seen every single person immersed in their phone, or looked around at a restaurant to see people, including couples on dates, all on their phones. That’s one reason why Edward Tenner, a cultural and technological historian and the author of  Why Things Bite Back: Technology and the Revenge of Unintended Consequences (1997), advocates the ‘deliberate creation and preservation of tech-free spaces’.
 Performers such as Hannah Gadsby, Alicia Keys, Dave Chappelle, Ariana Grande and Jack White use Yondr to create those spaces at their shows. Some hospitals, courts and schools now use them too, and people can rent them for weddings, conferences and parties. Beyond the pouches, many trains have a quiet car. Some restaurants offer discounts to diners who refrain from using phones; others ban phones entirely. These examples signify a bigger trend toward phone-free spaces.
 There’s a danger in being proscriptive about phones. Many people, including those with disabilities, rely on their phones to navigate and interact with their environments safely. According to Tenner, involuntary tech time-outs could  cause disconnection anxiety. Instead of banning phones entirely, the ideal solution is to create environments with an expectation around engaging with other people and one’s surroundings.
 Increasingly, research suggests that the masses are ready for this solution. According to the Pew Research Center, 54 per cent of teenagers and 36 per cent of parents in the US think that they spend too much time on their own phones, while 65 per cent of parents worry about their kids’ phone use, and roughly half of teens note that phones distract their parents. Despite being glued to their phones, my college students  express disappointment at their dwindling in-person interactions. One former student, Cole Goldberg, mentioned in an email that his favourite times are Friday nights at Chabad, when there’s no phone use because of Shabbat. People gather for dinner and sometimes stay all night long, relishing uninterrupted conversations that would otherwise be impossible. ‘I think we all need some kind of Chabad once a week,’ Goldberg wrote.
 The mere presence of phones in social spaces creates interpersonal distance. Two experiments run by researchers at the University of Essex in 2012  found that people who met and talked while sitting at a table with a phone lying on it (unused) felt ‘less close with their partners and reported a lower quality of relationships than did partners who shared a conversation without a mobile phone present’. Those distancing effects were amplified if subjects discussed something particularly personal. Phone-free spaces shift focus back to social interaction, which can help people create the intimacy we try, usually unsuccessfully, to establish via screens.
 An event called Sync in Burlington, Vermont, unites likeminded people who want to connect in person. The event’s tagline is ‘Hang out with strangers. Leave your phone at home.’ In the summer of 2019, Yondr threw the first phone-free music and camping festival in the US. The three-day event in New York State had more than 300 attendees. Such events bring together people who value the importance of firsthand experiences so that they can collectively create and shape their own. People who can’t or won’t part with their devices can choose to avoid such gatherings, but they might become a mecca for those seeking meaningful, personal interactions.
 As people seek satisfaction in an increasingly technocentric world, more of us seem poised to push back against the ubiquity of phones in favour of prioritising firsthand experience. Yondr’s music festival took place on the 50th anniversary of Woodstock – the perfect occasion to reassess the purpose of such gatherings. What would have been lost if people were immersed in their phones while Jimi Hendrix, Janis Joplin and the Who performed, if countless people in the crowd had held phones aloft, recording the performances instead of truly experiencing them? Putting our phones away allows us to inhabit moments that otherwise become lost in the noise of social media – moments we get to experience only once.
title: 我们对真正连接的需求正在产生无电话空间
title_en: Our need for true connection is giving rise to phone-free spaces
